verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: have turned their backs, not their faces to me. I taught them again and again, but they refused to listen and learn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set up their detestable idols in the temple that is called by my name, and they dishonored it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the valley of Ben Hinnom they built worship sites for Baal to sacrifice their sons and daughters to Molech. I didn’t ask them to do this. It never entered my mind. I didn’t make Judah sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have said this about the city, ‘Because of wars, famines, and plagues it will be handed over to the king of Babylon.’ Now this is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am going to gather the people from all the lands where I scattered them in my anger, fury, and terrifying wrath. I will bring them back to this place and make them live here securely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will be my people, and I will be their Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give them the same attitude and the same purpose so that they will fear me as long as they live. This will be for their own good and for the good of their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make an eternal promise to them that I will never stop blessing them. I will make them fear me so that they will never turn away from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will enjoy blessing them. With all my heart and soul I will faithfully plant them in this land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh says: As I brought all these disasters on these people, so I will bring on them all these blessings that I have promised them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have said that this land is a wasteland, without people or animals living in it. You have also said that it has been handed over to the Babylonians. But people will once again buy fields in this land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will buy fields for money, sign deeds, seal them, and have people witness the signing of the deeds. This will happen in the territory of Benjamin, in the region of Jerusalem, in the cities of Judah, in the cities on the mountains, in the hill country, and in the Negev because I will bring them back from their captivity,” declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Jeremiah was still being held in the courtyard of the prison, Yahweh spoke his word to him a second time. Yahweh said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I made the earth, formed it, and set it in place. My name is Yahweh. This is what Yahweh says:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Call to me, and I will answer you. I will tell you great and mysterious things that you do not know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The houses in this city and the palaces of the kings of Judah have been torn down to be used against the dirt ramps and weapons of the Babylonians. This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says about this:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel fought the Babylonians. Now their houses are filled with the bodies of their own people I killed in my anger and my fury. I will hide my face from this city because of its wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But I will heal this city and restore it to health. I will heal its people, and I will give them peace and security.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will restore Judah and Israel and rebuild them as they were before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will cleanse them from all the sins that they have committed against me. I will forgive them for all the sins that they have committed against me and for rebelling against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jerusalem will be my source of joy, praise, and honor. All the nations on earth will hear about all the blessings that I will give to Jerusalem. They will be afraid and tremble because of all the prosperity that I will provide for it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh says: You have said that this place is ruined and that no people or animals live in it. It’s true! The cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem are deserted. No people or animals live there. But once again you will hear
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the sounds of joy and happiness and the sounds of brides and grooms. You will hear those who bring thank offerings to Yahweh’s temple say,
‘Give thanks to Yahweh Tsebaoth because Yahweh is good,
    because his mercy endures forever.’
I will restore the fortunes of the land to what they were before,” says Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth says: In this deserted place, where no people or animals live, and in all its cities, there will once again be pastures where shepherds can rest their flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the cities on the mountains, in the foothills, in the Negev, in the territory of Benjamin, in the area around Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, shepherds will once again count their sheep,” says Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The days are coming,” declares Yahweh, “when I will keep the promise that I made to Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days and at that time, I will cause a righteous Tsemach to spring up for David. He will do what is fair and right in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days Judah will be saved and Jerusalem will live securely. Jerusalem will be called Yahweh Tsidqenu.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This what Yahweh says: David will never fail to have a descendant sitting on the throne of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levitical priests will never fail to have a descendant in my presence to sacrifice burnt offerings, to burn grain offerings, and to prepare daily sacrifices.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh says: Suppose you could break my arrangement with day and night so that they wouldn’t come at their proper time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then my arrangement with my servant David could be broken, and he would not have a descendant to rule on his throne. The arrangement with my servants the Levitical priests could also be broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will multiply the descendants of my servant David and the Levites who serve me like the stars of heaven that cannot be counted and the sand on the seashore that cannot be measured.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Haven’t you noticed what these people have said? They have said that Yahweh has rejected the two families he has chosen. They despise my people, and they no longer consider them a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh says: Suppose I hadn’t made an arrangement with day and night or made laws for heaven and earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I would reject the descendants of Jacob and of my servant David. I would not let any of David’s descendants rule the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. However, I will restore their fortunes and love them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah when King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, his entire army, and all the kingdoms and people that he ruled were attacking Jerusalem and all its cities. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says: Go to King Zedekiah of Judah, and tell him, ‘Yahweh says: I’m going to hand this city over to the king of Babylon, and he will burn it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will not escape from him. You will certainly be captured and handed over to him. You will see the king of Babylon with your own eyes, and he will talk to you face to face. Then you will go to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘Listen to the word of Yahweh, King Zedekiah of Judah. This is what Yahweh says about you: You will not die in war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will die peacefully. People will burn funeral fires for you as they did for your ancestors, the kings who lived before you. They will say, “Oh, master,” as they mourn for you. I have spoken my word, declares Yahweh.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Jeremiah told all these things to King Zedekiah of Judah in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did this when the army of the king of Babylon was attacking Jerusalem and the cities of Lachish and Azekah. These were the only fortified cities of Judah that were left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah after King Zedekiah and all the people in Jerusalem promised to free their slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone was supposed to free his Hebrew slaves, both male and female. No one was supposed to keep another Jew as a slave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials and all the people agreed and promised to free their male and female slaves and not to keep them as slaves anymore. So they set them free.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But afterwards, they changed their minds and took back the men and women they had freed and made them their slaves again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says: I put a condition on the promise I made to your ancestors when I brought them from Egypt, where they were slaves. I said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Every seven years each of you must free any Hebrews who sold themselves to you. When they have served you for six years, you must set them free.’ But your ancestors refused to obey me or listen to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Recently, you changed and did what I consider right. You agreed to free your neighbors, and you made a promise in my presence, in the temple that is called by my name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you have changed again and dishonored me. You brought back the male and female slaves that you had set free to live their own lives. You have forced them to be your male and female slaves again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh says: You didn’t obey me. You haven’t freed your relatives and neighbors. Now I am going to free you,” declares Yahweh. “I will free you to die in wars, plagues, and famines. I will make all the kingdoms of the world horrified at the thought of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will hand over the people who have rejected my promise. They have not kept the terms of the promise which they made in my presence when they cut a calf in two and passed between its pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will hand over the officials of Judah and Jerusalem, the palace officials, the priests, and all the common people who passed between the pieces of the calf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will hand them over to their enemies who want to kill them, and their corpses will be food for birds and wild animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will hand King Zedekiah of Judah and his officials over to their enemies who want to kill them and to the army of the king of Babylon, the army that has withdrawn from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am going to give a command,” declares Yahweh. “I will bring that army back to this city to attack it, capture it, and burn it down. I will destroy the cities of Judah so that no one will live there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah during the reign of Jehoiakim, son of King Josiah of Judah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go to the family of Rechab and talk to them. Take them into one of the side rooms in Yahweh’s temple, and offer them a drink of wine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I took Jaazaniah, who was the son of Jeremiah and the grandson of Habazziniah, and I took Jaazaniah’s brothers and all his sons—the whole family of Rechab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I brought them into Yahweh’s temple, into the side room of the sons of Hanan. (He was Igdaliah’s son, the man of Elohim.) It was next to the room of the officials and above the side room of Maaseiah, Shallum’s son, the doorkeeper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I set cups and pitchers filled with wine in front of the family of Rechab. I said to them, “Drink some wine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered, “We don’t drink wine, because our ancestor Jonadab, Rechab’s son, gave us this order: ‘You and your descendants must never drink wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Never build any houses or plant any fields or vineyards. You must never have any of these things. You must always live in tents so that you may live for a long time in the land where you are staying.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We, along with our wives, sons, and daughters, have obeyed our ancestor Jonadab, Rechab’s son, in everything he ordered us to do. We have never drunk wine,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: built houses to live in, or owned vineyards, pastures, or grainfields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We live in tents, and we have obeyed everything our ancestor Jonadab ordered us to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon invaded this land, we said, ‘Let’s go to Jerusalem to escape the Babylonian and Aramean armies.’ That’s why we are living in Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: Tell the people of Judah and those who live in Jerusalem, ‘Won’t you ever learn your lesson and obey my words? declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab, Rechab’s son, ordered his descendants not to drink wine. This order has been carried out. His descendants have not drunk any wine to this day, because they have obeyed their ancestor’s order. I have spoken to you again and again, but you have refused to listen to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have sent all my servants the prophets to you again and again. They said, “Turn from your evil ways, do what is right, and don’t follow other gods in order to serve them. Then you will live in the land that I gave you and your ancestors.” However, you refused to listen to me or obey me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Jonadab, Rechab’s son, have carried out the orders of their ancestor, but you refuse to listen to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘This is what Yahweh Elohim Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: I am going to bring on Judah and on all those who live in Jerusalem all the disasters that I threatened. I have spoken to them, but they didn’t listen. I called to them, but they didn’t answer.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to the family of Rechab, “This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: You obeyed the order of your ancestor Jonadab, followed all his instructions, and did exactly what he told you to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So this is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: A descendant of Jonadab, Rechab’s son, will always serve me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourth year of the reign of Jehoiakim, son of King Josiah of Judah, Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take a scroll, and write on it everything that I have dictated to you about Israel, Judah, and all the other nations from the time I spoke to you during the reign of Josiah until today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Maybe the nation of Judah will hear about all the disasters that I plan to bring on them, and they will turn from their wicked ways. Then I will forgive their wickedness and their sins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah called Baruch, son of Neriah. Jeremiah dictated everything that Yahweh had told him, and Baruch wrote it all down on a scroll.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah told Baruch, “I’m no longer allowed to go to Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On a day of fasting, you must read from the scroll Yahweh’s message that you wrote as I dictated. You must read it to the people in Yahweh’s temple. You must also read it to all the people of Judah when they come from their cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Maybe their prayers will come into Yahweh’s presence, and they will turn from their evil ways. Yahweh has threatened these people with his terrifying anger and fury.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch, son of Neriah, did as the prophet Jeremiah commanded him. In Yahweh’s temple he read from the scroll everything that Yahweh had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the ninth month of the fifth year of the reign of Jehoiakim, son of King Josiah of Judah, a time for fasting was called. It was a time for all the people in Jerusalem and for everyone who was coming from any city in Judah to Jerusalem to fast in Yahweh’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Baruch read the scroll containing the words of Jeremiah. Baruch read it to all the people in Yahweh’s temple in the room of the scribe Gemariah, son of Shaphan, in the upper courtyard at the entrance of New Gate of Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah, who was the son of Gemariah and the grandson of Shaphan, heard Baruch read from the scroll everything Yahweh had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went down to the scribe’s room in the king’s palace where all the scribes were sitting. The scribe Elishama, Delaiah (son of Shemaiah), Elnathan (son of Achbor), Gemariah (son of Shaphan), Zedekiah (son of Hananiah), and all the other officials were there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah told them everything he heard Baruch read from the scroll publicly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the officials sent Jehudi, who was the son of Nethaniah, the grandson of Shelemiah, and the great-grandson of Cushi, to Baruch. Jehudi said to Baruch, “Bring the scroll that you read publicly, and come with me.” Baruch, son of Neriah, took the scroll and went with him to see the officers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They said to Baruch, “Please sit down, and read it to us.”
So Baruch read it to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard everything, they turned to each other in terror. They said to Baruch, “We must tell the king everything.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they asked Baruch, “Please tell us how you wrote all this. Did Jeremiah dictate it to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch answered, “He dictated everything to me, and I wrote it on the scroll in ink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials said to Baruch, “You and Jeremiah must hide. Don’t let anyone know where you are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they put the scroll in the side room of the scribe Elishama, they went to the king in the courtyard and told him everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king sent Jehudi to get the scroll. He took the scroll from the side room of the scribe Elishama. Jehudi read it to the king and all the officials standing by the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was the ninth month, and the king was in his winter house sitting in front of the fire in the fireplace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Jehudi read three or four columns, the king would cut them off with a scribe’s knife and throw them into the fire in the fireplace. He did this until the whole scroll was burned up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all his attendants didn’t show any fear or tear their clothes in fear when they heard everything being read.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even when Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah urged the king not to burn the scroll, he refused to listen to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king commanded Jerahmeel (the king’s son), Seraiah (son of Azriel), and Shelemiah (son of Abdeel) to arrest the scribe Baruch and the prophet Jeremiah. But Yahweh had hidden Baruch and Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the king burned up the scroll that Baruch had written and that Jeremiah had dictated, Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take another scroll, and write on it everything that was written on the scroll that King Jehoiakim of Judah burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say about King Jehoiakim of Judah, ‘This is what Yahweh says: You burned this scroll, and you asked Jeremiah, “Why did you write that the king of Babylon will certainly come to destroy this land and take away people and animals?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Yahweh says about King Jehoiakim of Judah: He will have no one to sit on David’s throne, and his own corpse will be thrown out and exposed to the heat of day and the cold of night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish him, his descendants, and his attendants for their wickedness. They refused to listen. So I will bring on them, on those who live in Jerusalem, and on the people of Judah all the disasters that I have threatened.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to the scribe Baruch, son of Neriah. As Jeremiah dictated, Baruch wrote on it everything that was on the scroll that King Jehoiakim of Judah had burned. They added many similar messages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon appointed Zedekiah, son of Josiah, to be king of Judah. Zedekiah succeeded Jehoiakin, son of Jehoiakim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zedekiah, his administrators, and the common people didn’t listen to what Yahweh had spoken through the prophet Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah sent Jehucal (son of Shelemiah) and the priest Zephaniah (son of Maaseiah) to the prophet Jeremiah. They asked him, “Please pray to Yahweh our Elohim for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah was still free to come and go among the people. The people of Jerusalem hadn’t put him in prison yet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s army had come from Egypt, and when the Babylonians who were blockading Jerusalem heard this news, they retreated from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke his word to the prophet Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says: Say this to the king of Judah, who sent you to get advice from me: ‘Pharaoh’s army has come out to help you. But it will go back to Egypt, its own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Babylonians will return. They will attack the city, capture it, and burn it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘This is what Yahweh says: Don’t deceive yourselves by thinking that the Babylonians will leave you. They will not leave you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if you would defeat the entire Babylonian army so that they had only a few badly wounded men left in their tents, they would get up and burn down this city.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Babylonian army had retreated from Jerusalem because Pharaoh’s army was coming.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah wanted to leave Jerusalem and go to the territory of Benjamin to take possession of his property there among the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when he came to Benjamin Gate, the captain of the guard there, whose name was Irijah, son of Shelemiah and grandson of Hananiah, arrested the prophet Jeremiah. He said, “You’re deserting to the Babylonians!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah answered, “That’s a lie! I’m not deserting to the Babylonians.” But Irijah wouldn’t listen to him. Irijah arrested Jeremiah and took him to the officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials were so angry with Jeremiah that they beat him and put him in prison in the scribe Jonathan’s house, which had been turned into a prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah went into a prison cell, and he stayed there a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then King Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah, and the king asked him privately in the palace, “Is there any message from Yahweh?”
Jeremiah answered, “Yes! There is a message from Yahweh. You will be handed over to the king of Babylon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah asked King Zedekiah, “What crime have I committed against you, your administrators, or these people? Why have you put me in prison?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where are the prophets who told you that the king of Babylon wouldn’t attack you and this land?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, Your Majesty, please listen, and accept my plea for mercy. Don’t return me to the scribe Jonathan’s house, or I will die there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah gave the command to have Jeremiah put in the courtyard of the prison. He gave him a loaf of bread every day from the bakers’ street until all the bread in the city was gone. So Jeremiah stayed in the courtyard of the prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shephatiah (son of Mattan), Gedaliah (son of Pashhur), Jucal (son of Shelemiah), and Pashhur (son of Malchiah) heard that Jeremiah was speaking to all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They heard Jeremiah say, “This is what Yahweh says: Those who stay in this city will die in wars, famines, or plagues. But those who surrender to the Babylonians will live. They will escape with their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh says: This city will certainly be handed over to the army of the king of Babylon, and it will capture the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials said to the king, “Have this man put to death. He discourages the soldiers who are left in this city and all the people by telling them such things. This man is not trying to help these people; he’s trying to hurt them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah answered, “He’s in your hands. I won’t do anything to stop you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took Jeremiah and threw him into the cistern of Malchiah, the king’s son. It was in the courtyard of the prison. They used ropes to lower Jeremiah into the cistern. There was no water in the cistern, only mud, and Jeremiah sank in the mud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But an official in the royal palace, Ebed Melech from Sudan, heard that they had put Jeremiah in the cistern. The king happened to be sitting at Benjamin Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed Melech left the royal palace and spoke to the king at Benjamin Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your Majesty, everything that these men have done to the prophet Jeremiah is wrong. They have thrown him into the cistern, where he’ll starve to death, because there’s no more bread in the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king gave Ebed Melech from Sudan this command: “Take 30 men from here, and lift the prophet Jeremiah out of the cistern before he dies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ebed Melech took the men with him and went to the royal palace, to a room under the treasury. He took rags and torn clothes from there and lowered them with ropes to Jeremiah in the cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed Melech from Sudan said to Jeremiah, “Put these rags and torn clothes under your arms to protect you from the ropes.” Jeremiah did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They used the ropes to pull Jeremiah up and lift him out of the cistern. Then Jeremiah stayed in the courtyard of the prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah sent for the prophet Jeremiah and brought him to the third entrance in Yahweh’s temple. “I’m going to ask you a question,” the king said to Jeremiah. “Don’t hide anything from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah answered Zedekiah, “If I answer you, you’ll kill me. If I give you advice, you won’t listen to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Zedekiah secretly swore an oath to Jeremiah, “Yahweh gave us life. As Yahweh lives, I will not kill you or hand you over to these men who want to kill you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “This is what Yahweh Elohim Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: If you surrender to the officers of the king of Babylon, you will live, and this city will not be burned. You and your household will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you don’t surrender to the officers of the king of Babylon, this city will be handed over to the Babylonians. They will burn it down, and you will not escape from them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah answered Jeremiah, “I’m afraid of the Jews who have deserted to the Babylonians. The Babylonians may hand me over to them, and they will torture me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said, “You will not be handed over to them. Obey Yahweh by doing what I’m telling you. Then everything will go well for you, and you will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to surrender, this is what Yahweh has shown me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the women who are left in the palace of Judah’s king will be brought out to the officers of the king of Babylon. These women will say:
‘Your trusted friends have misled you and used you.
    Your feet are stuck in the mud, and your friends have deserted you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All your wives and children will be brought to the Babylonians. You will not escape from them. You will be captured by the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “Don’t let anyone know about this conversation, or you will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials may find out that I’ve been talking with you. They may come to you and say, ‘Tell us what you said to the king and what the king said to you. Don’t hide anything from us, or we’ll kill you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they come to you, say to them, ‘I asked the king not to send me back to Jonathan’s house to die there.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials came to Jeremiah and questioned him. He told them exactly what the king had told him to say. So they stopped questioning him, because they hadn’t heard his conversation with the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah stayed in the courtyard of the prison until the day Jerusalem was captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the tenth month of Zedekiah’s ninth year as king of Judah, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked Jerusalem with his entire army and blockaded it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the ninth day of the fourth month of Zedekiah’s eleventh year as king, they broke into the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the officers of the king of Babylon came in and sat in Middle Gate: Nergal (the quartermaster), Samgar Nebo (the chief officer), Nergal (the quartermaster and the chief fortuneteller), and all the rest of the officers of the king of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Zedekiah of Judah and all the soldiers saw them, they fled. They left the city at night by way of the king’s garden through the gate between the two walls, and they took the road to the plain of Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Babylonian army pursued them and caught up with Zedekiah in the plain of Jericho. They arrested him and brought him to Babylon’s King Nebuchadnezzar at Riblah in the territory of Hamath. The king of Babylon passed sentence on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon slaughtered Zedekiah’s sons as Zedekiah watched at Riblah. He also slaughtered all the leaders of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he blinded Zedekiah, put him in bronze shackles, and took him to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Babylonians burned down the royal palace and the people’s homes, and they tore down the walls of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuzaradan, Babylon’s captain of the guard, captured the few people left in the city, those who surrendered to him, and the rest of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, left some poor people who had nothing in the land of Judah. At that time he gave them vineyards and farms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon gave Nebuzaradan an order concerning Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take him, and look after him. Don’t harm him in any way, but do for him whatever he asks.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuzaradan (the captain of the guard), Nebushazban (the chief official), Nergal (the quartermaster and the chief fortuneteller), and all the other leaders of the king of Babylon sent for Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took Jeremiah out of the courtyard of the prison and handed him over to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, to take him home. So he lived among the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Jeremiah was still confined in the courtyard of the prison, Yahweh spoke his word to him. Yahweh said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say to Ebed Melech from Sudan, ‘This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: I’m going to carry out my threat against this city by bringing disaster on it instead of prosperity. At that time these things will happen as you watch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But at that time I will rescue you, declares Yahweh. You will not be handed over to those you fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will certainly rescue you. You will not die in war. You will escape with your life because you trusted me, declares Yahweh.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah after Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, let him go at Ramah. Nebuzaradan found Jeremiah in chains along with the captives of Jerusalem and Judah who were being taken to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The captain of the guard took Jeremiah aside and said to him, “Yahweh your Elohim threatened to bring this disaster on this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has carried out his threat. Yahweh did as he promised because you Israelites have sinned against him and refused to obey him. That is why this has happened to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today I’m removing the chains from your hands. If you would like to come with me to Babylon, come, and I’ll look after you. But if you don’t want to come with me to Babylon, don’t come. The whole land is yours. Go wherever you want.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If you wish to remain, then go back to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, whom the king of Babylon appointed to govern the cities of Judah. Live among the people with him, or go anywhere you want.” The captain of the guard gave Jeremiah some food and a present and let him go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah went to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, at Mizpah and lived with him among the people who were left in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the army commanders and their men who were in the field heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, to govern the country and some of the country’s poorest men, women, and children who had not been taken away to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the commanders who went with their men to Gedaliah at Mizpah: Ishmael (son of Nethaniah), Johanan and Jonathan (sons of Kareah), Seraiah (son of Tanhumeth), the sons of Ephai from Netophah, and Jezaniah, who was the son of a man from Maacah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, swore an oath to them and their men. He said, “Don’t be afraid to serve the Babylonians. Live in this country, serve the king of Babylon, and you will prosper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m going to live in Mizpah and represent you when the Babylonians come to us. Gather grapes, summer fruit, and olive oil, and put them in storage jars. Live in the cities you have taken over.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, all the Jews who were in Moab, Ammon, Edom, and in all the other countries heard that the king of Babylon had left a few survivors in Judah and had appointed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, to govern them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the Jews returned from all the places where they had been scattered. They came to Judah and to Gedaliah at Mizpah. They gathered a large harvest of grapes and summer fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kareah’s son Johanan and all the army commanders who were still in the country came to Gedaliah at Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They asked him, “Do you know that King Baalis of the Ammonites has sent Ishmael, Nethaniah’s son, to kill you?” However, Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, didn’t believe them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Johanan, Kareah’s son, secretly asked Gedaliah at Mizpah, “Let me kill Ishmael, Nethaniah’s son. No one will know about it. Why should he kill you? All the Jews who have gathered around you would scatter. What is left of Judah would disappear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, told Johanan, Kareah’s son, “Don’t do that! What you are saying about Ishmael is a lie.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventh month Ishmael (son of Nethaniah and grandson of Elishama, a descendant of the royal family and of the king’s officers) went with ten men to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, at Mizpah. As they ate together at Mizpah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, and the ten men who were with him got up, drew their swords, and killed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan. So they assassinated the man whom the king of Babylon had appointed to govern the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael also killed all the Jews who were with Gedaliah at Mizpah as well as the Babylonian soldiers that he found there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The day after the murder of Gedaliah, before anyone knew about it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 80 men arrived from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria. Their beards were shaved off, their clothes were torn, and cuts were on their bodies. They brought grain offerings and incense to Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, left Mizpah to meet them, crying as he went. When he met them, he said to them, “Come to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came into the city, Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, and his men slaughtered them and threw them into a cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, ten men from the group had said to Ishmael, “Don’t kill us! We have wheat, barley, olive oil, and honey hidden in the country.” So he left them alone and didn’t kill them along with the others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, the cistern where Ishmael threw all the bodies of the men he had killed was the same one that King Asa made as a part of his defense against King Baasha of Israel. Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, filled it with the bodies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ishmael took captive the rest of the people who were at Mizpah. He captured the king’s daughters and all the other people who had been left at Mizpah. They were the people whom Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had put under the control of Gedaliah, son of Ahikam. Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, took them captive and left for Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Kareah’s son Johanan and all the army commanders who were with him heard about all the crimes Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, had done,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they took all their men and went to fight Ishmael. They caught up with him at the large pool in Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the people who were with Ishmael saw Kareah’s son Johanan and all the army commanders who were with him, they were glad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people Ishmael had taken captive at Mizpah turned and ran to Kareah’s son Johanan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael and eight of his men escaped from Johanan and fled to Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Kareah’s son Johanan and all the army commanders who were with him brought back the rest of the people of Mizpah whom he had rescued from Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, after Ishmael had killed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam. Johanan brought back men, women, children, soldiers, and commanders from Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they left Gibeon, they stayed near Bethlehem at Geruth Kimham on their way to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were afraid of the Babylonians because Ishmael had killed Gedaliah whom the king of Babylon had appointed to govern the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the army commanders along with Kareah’s son Johanan and Hoshaiah’s son Jezaniah and all the people, from the least important to the most important, came to the prophet Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “Please listen to our request, and pray to Yahweh your Elohim for all of us who are left here. As you can see, there are only a few of us left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let Yahweh your Elohim tell us where we should go and what we should do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Jeremiah answered them, “I have listened to your request. I will pray to Yahweh your Elohim as you have requested, and I will tell you everything Yahweh says. I won’t keep anything from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Jeremiah, “May Yahweh be a true and faithful witness against us if we don’t do exactly what Yahweh your Elohim tells us to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will obey Yahweh our Elohim to whom we are sending you, whether it’s good or bad. Yes, we will obey Yahweh our Elohim so that everything will go well for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After ten days Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah called Kareah’s son Johanan, all the army commanders who were with him, and all the people from the least important to the most important.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said to them, “You sent me to plead your case humbly to Yahweh. This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suppose you stay in this land. Then I will build you up and not tear you down. I will plant you and not uproot you. I will change my plans about the disaster I’ve brought on you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be afraid of the king of Babylon, whom you now fear. Don’t be afraid of him, declares Yahweh. I’m with you. I will save you and rescue you from his power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will have compassion on you. I will make him have compassion on you and return you to your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But suppose you say, ‘We won’t stay in this land,’ and you disobey Yahweh your Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you say, ‘We’ll go to Egypt, where we won’t have to see war, hear the sound of a ram’s horn, or be hungry. We’ll stay there.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, listen to the word of Yahweh, you people who are left in Judah. This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: Suppose you’re determined to go to Egypt, and you go and live there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the wars you fear will catch up with you in Egypt. The famines you dread will follow you to Egypt, and you will die there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people who decide to go and live in Egypt will die in wars, famines, and plagues. No one will survive or escape the disasters I will bring on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: As my anger and my fury were poured out on those who live in Jerusalem, so my fury will be poured out on you if you go to Egypt. You will become a curse word. You will become something ridiculed, cursed, and disgraced. You won’t see this place again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yahweh has told you people who are left in Judah not to go to Egypt. You need to know that I am warning you today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You only deceived yourselves when you sent me to Yahweh your Elohim and said, ‘Pray to Yahweh our Elohim for us, and tell us everything that Yahweh our Elohim says, and we’ll do it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have told you today, but you won’t obey anything Yahweh your Elohim sent me to tell you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, you need to know that you will die in wars, famines, or plagues in the place where you want to go and live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah finished telling all the people the message from Yahweh their Elohim. He told them everything Yahweh their Elohim sent him to tell them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah (son of Hoshaiah), Johanan (son of Kareah), and all the arrogant people said to Jeremiah, “You’re lying! Yahweh our Elohim didn’t send you to tell us that we must not go to live in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Baruch, son of Neriah, has turned you against us in order to hand us over to the Babylonians. Then they will kill us or take us as captives to Babylon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Johanan (son of Kareah), all the army commanders, and all the people didn’t obey Yahweh. They didn’t stay in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Johanan (son of Kareah) and all the army commanders took all the people who were left in Judah to Egypt. These were all the people who had come back to Judah from the places where they had been scattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took men, women, children, and the king’s daughters. They took every person whom Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had left with Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, including the prophet Jeremiah and Baruch, son of Neriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They didn’t listen to Yahweh, so they went to Egypt. They went as far as Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah in Tahpanhes. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take some large stones, and bury them under the brick pavement at the entrance to the Pharaoh’s palace in Tahpanhes. Do this while the people of Judah watch you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to them, ‘This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: I’m going to send for my servant King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. I will set his throne over these stones that I buried, and I will spread his royal canopy above them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will defeat Egypt. He will bring death to those who are supposed to die. He will capture those who are supposed to be captured. He will kill in battle those who are supposed to be killed in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will set fire to the temples of Egypt’s gods. He will burn down the temples and take their gods captive. Nebuchadnezzar will put on Egypt as his coat as a shepherd puts on his coat. He will leave Egypt peacefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At Beth Shemesh he will break the monuments in Egypt and burn down the temples of Egypt’s gods.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke his word to Jeremiah about all the Jews living in Egypt at Migdol, Tahpanhes, Noph, and Pathros.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: You have seen all the disasters I brought on Jerusalem and on all the cities of Judah. Today they are deserted ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is because their people did evil, and they made me angry. They went to burn incense and serve other gods that neither you nor your ancestors heard of.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have sent my servants the prophets to you again and again to tell you not to do these detestable things that I hate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you wouldn’t listen or pay attention. You wouldn’t turn from your wicked ways and wouldn’t stop burning incense as an offering to other gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why my fury and anger were poured out and continued to burn in the cities of Judah and on the streets of Jerusalem. So they became the desolate ruin that they are today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, this is what Yahweh Elohim Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: Why do you bring this terrible disaster on yourselves? Why do you keep destroying men, women, children, and babies from Judah until none are left?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why do you make me angry by burning incense to other gods in Egypt, where you have come to live. You will destroy yourselves and be cursed and ridiculed by all the nations on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have you forgotten the wicked things done by your ancestors, by the kings of Judah and their wives, and by you and your wives in Judah and on the streets of Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have not humbled yourselves even to this day. You haven’t feared me or lived your lives by my teachings or by my decrees that I gave your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: I’m going to bring disaster on you and destroy all of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take away from Judah those who are left, those who were determined to go to live in Egypt. They will die in Egypt. All of them, from the least important to the most important, will die in wars or be brought to an end by famines. They will become something cursed, ridiculed, and disgraced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish those living in Egypt as I punished Jerusalem with wars, famines, and plagues.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: None of the people of Judah who went to live in Egypt will survive or return to Judah, where they long to return and live. Only a few refugees will return there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men who knew that their wives were burning incense to other gods, all the women who were standing there, and all the people who lived at Pathros in Egypt answered Jeremiah. They said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We won’t listen to the message that you have spoken to us in Yahweh’s name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will do everything we said we would do. We will burn incense to the queen of heaven and pour out wine offerings to her as our ancestors, our kings, and our officials did in the cities of Judah and on the streets of Jerusalem. We had plenty to eat then, and we lived comfortably and saw no disaster.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But since we stopped burning incense to the queen of heaven and pouring out wine offerings to her, we have had nothing but wars and famines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The women added, “When we burned incense to the queen of heaven, poured out wine offerings to her, and made cakes for her with her image on them, do you think our husbands didn’t approve?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people, both men and women, to everyone who answered him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Doesn’t Yahweh remember that you burned incense in the cities of Judah and on the streets of Jerusalem along with your ancestors, your kings and your officials, and the people in the land?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh could no longer bear the wicked and detestable things you did. That is why your land has become something ruined, destroyed, and cursed. No one lives in that land today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You burned incense as offerings to other gods, sinned against Yahweh, and wouldn’t obey him. You didn’t live by his teachings, decrees, or written instructions. That is why you have met with this disaster as it is today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people, including the women, “Listen to the word of Yahweh, all you people of Judah who are in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says: You and your wives made promises, and you have kept them. You said, ‘We will certainly do what we vow. We will burn incense to the queen of heaven and pour out wine offerings to her.’
“So go ahead. Keep your vows, and do what you vow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But listen to the word of Yahweh, all you people of Judah who live in Egypt. ‘I swear by my great name,’ says Yahweh, ‘that no one from Judah who lives anywhere in Egypt will ever again call on my name and take the oath, “As Adonay Yahweh lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am going to watch over them. I am going to watch over them to bring disasters, not blessings. In Egypt the people from Judah will die in wars and famines until everyone is gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who escape the wars will return to Judah from Egypt. Then all the people of Judah who went to live in Egypt will know whose words have come true, mine or theirs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give you this sign,’ declares Yahweh. ‘I will punish you in this place so that you will know that my threats of disaster will happen to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Yahweh says: I’m going to hand Pharaoh Hophra, king of Egypt, over to his enemies and to those who want to kill him, just as I handed over King Zedekiah of Judah to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and to those who wanted to kill him.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that the prophet Jeremiah spoke to Baruch, son of Neriah. Baruch wrote these things on a scroll as Jeremiah dictated them during the fourth year that Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, was king of Judah. Jeremiah said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says to you, Baruch:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You said, ‘I’m so miserable! Yahweh has added grief to my pain. I’m worn out from groaning. I can’t find any rest.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say this to Baruch, ‘This is what Yahweh says: I will tear down what I have built. I will uproot what I have planted throughout the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Are you looking for great things for yourself? Don’t look for them, because I’m going to bring disaster on all people, declares Yahweh. But wherever you go I will let you escape with your life.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke this message to the prophet Jeremiah about the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message about Egypt, about the army of Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt. King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon defeated his army at Carchemish along the Euphrates River during the fourth year that Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, was king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get your large and small shields ready; advance into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Harness your horses. Mount up, you horsemen.
    Take your positions, and put on your helmets.
    Polish your spears.
    Put on your armor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What do I see in them?
    They are terrified.
        They are retreating.
    Their warriors are defeated.
        They flee without looking back.
            Terror is all around them,” declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The infantry can’t flee.
    The warriors can’t escape.
    They stumble and fall in the north by the Euphrates River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is this, rising like the Nile River,
    like streams that flow swiftly?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt is like the rising Nile River,
    like a river quickly overflowing its banks.
    Egypt says, ‘I will rise; I will cover the earth.
    I will destroy cities and the people in them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go into battle, you horsemen.
    Drive wildly, you chariot drivers.
    March into battle, you warriors,
    you warriors from Sudan and Put who carry shields,
    you warriors from Lydia who use bows and arrows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That day belongs to Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth.
    It is a day of vengeance when he will take revenge on his enemies.
        His sword will devour until it has had enough,
            and it will drink their blood until it’s full.
        Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth will offer them as sacrifices
            in the north by the Euphrates River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go to Gilead, and get medicine, dear people of Egypt.
    You have used many medicines without results; you can’t be cured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The nations have heard of your shame; your cry fills the earth.
    One warrior will stumble over another,
    and both will fall together.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke this message to the prophet Jeremiah about the coming of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, who will defeat Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Tell this in Egypt; announce this in Migdol.
    Make it known in Memphis and in Tahpanhes.
    Say, ‘Take your positions, and get ready.
    Swords will kill those around you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why should your soldiers be cut down?
    They can’t stand because Yahweh will push them down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They have repeatedly stumbled, and now they have fallen.
    They say to each other,
    ‘Get up! Let’s go back to our people,
        to the land where we were born,
            and escape our enemy’s sword.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There they will cry, ‘Pharaoh, king of Egypt, is a big windbag.
    He has missed his chance.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“As I live,” declares the Melek, whose name is Yahweh Tsebaoth,
    “someone who is like Mount Tabor among the mountains will come.
    Someone who is like Mount Carmel by the sea will come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pack your bags, inhabitants of Egypt,
    because you will be taken away as captives.
        Memphis will become a dreary wasteland,
            a pile of rubble where no one lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Egypt is like a beautiful cow,
    but a horsefly from the north will attack it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt’s hired soldiers are like fattened calves.
    They will turn and run away together.
    They won’t stand their ground.
        The day of destruction is coming.
            At that time they will be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt will hiss like a snake as it slithers away.
    Its enemies will come with full force.
    They will attack it with axes like those who chop wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will cut down the forest,” declares Yahweh,
    “since Egypt can’t be found.
    They are more numerous than locusts; they can’t be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people of Egypt will be put to shame.
    They will be handed over to the people from the north.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says,
“I’m going to punish Amon, who is the god of Thebes.
    I will also punish Pharaoh, Egypt, its gods, its kings,
    and whoever trusts Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll hand them over to those who want to kill them,
    to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and his officers.
    Afterward, they will live in peace as they did long ago,”
    declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Don’t be afraid, my servant Jacob.
    Don’t be terrified, Israel.
    I’m going to rescue you and your descendants from a faraway land,
        from the land where you are captives.
    Then Jacob’s descendants will again have undisturbed peace,
    and no one will make them afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t be afraid, my servant Jacob,” declares Yahweh.
    “I am with you.
    I will completely destroy all the nations where I scattered you,
        but I will not completely destroy you.
            I will correct you with justice.
                I won’t let you go entirely unpunished.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh spoke this message to the prophet Jeremiah about the Philistines before Pharaoh defeated Gaza.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh says:
Water is rising in the north.
    It will become an overflowing river.
        It will overflow the land and everything in it,
            the cities and those who live in them.
    People will cry out and everyone who lives in the land will cry loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will hear the sound of galloping war horses,
    the rattling of enemy chariots,
        and the rumbling of their wheels.
    Fathers who lack courage abandon their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The time has come to destroy all the Philistines,
    to cut off from Tyre and Sidon any Philistine
        who might have escaped to get help.
    Yahweh will destroy the Philistines
    and anyone who is left from the island of Crete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Gaza will shave its head in mourning.
    Ashkelon will be destroyed.
    How long will you cut yourselves, you people left on the plains?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You cry out, “Sword of Yahweh,
    how long will you keep on fighting?
        Go back into your scabbard.
            Stay there and rest!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How can the sword of Yahweh rest?
    Yahweh has ordered it to attack Ashkelon and the coast.
        He has put it there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, says about Moab:
How horrible it will be for Nebo; it will be destroyed.
    Kiriathaim will be put to shame; it will be captured.
    Its stronghold will be put to shame and torn down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People will no longer praise Moab.
    The people in Heshbon will plan Moab’s destruction.
        “Let’s destroy that nation!”
    You will be silenced, city of Madmen.
        Death will come after you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People will cry out from Horonaim, “Looting and great destruction!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be broken.
    Its little ones will cry out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People go up the pass of Luhith, crying bitterly as they go.
    On the road down to Horonaim they have heard
        the distressful cry of destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Run away! Run for your lives!
                Run like a wild donkey in the desert.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Since you trust the things you do and your treasures,
    you will be captured.
    Chemosh will go into captivity with all its priests and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The destroyer will come to every city, and no city will escape.
    The valley will be destroyed, and the plain will be laid waste
    as Yahweh has threatened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Put salt on Moab.
    It will be destroyed.
    Its cities will become deserted ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cursed are those who neglect doing Yahweh’s work.
    Cursed are those who keep their swords from killing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Moab has lived securely ever since it was young.
    Its people are like wine left to settle in a jar.
        They aren’t poured from one jar to another.
        They haven’t gone into captivity.
            That is why its flavor has remained the same,
                and its aroma hasn’t changed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why the days are coming,” declares Yahweh,
    “when I will send people to pour Moab out of its jars
        and to smash its pitchers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moab will be ashamed of Chemosh
    as the nation of Israel was ashamed when it trusted Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How can you say, ‘We are soldiers and warriors’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The enemy will attack Moab and destroy its cities.
    Its finest young men will be slaughtered,”
        declares the Melek, whose name is Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Moab’s destruction is coming near; disaster is coming quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mourn over it, all of its neighbors and everyone who knows its fame.
    Say, ‘Look at the strong staff, the beautiful rod, that is broken!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“People of Dibon, come down from your place of honor
    and sit on the dry ground.
    The destroyers of Moab will attack you.
    They will destroy your fortresses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Stand by the road in Aroer, and watch.
    Ask those who are fleeing
        and those who are escaping what is happening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will answer, ‘Moab is disgraced; it is defeated.
    Shout loudly, and cry.
        Tell the news in Arnon that Moab is destroyed.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Judgment has come to all the cities on the plain: to Holon, Jahzah, Mephaath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dibon, Nebo, Beth Diblathaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kiriathaim, Beth Gamul, Beth Meon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kerioth, Bozrah, and on all the cities of Moab, far and near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Moab’s horn is cut off, and its arm is broken,”
    declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Get the people of Moab drunk; they have spoken against Yahweh.
    They will wallow in their own vomit, and people will laugh at them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People of Moab, didn’t you laugh at the people of Israel?
    Were they caught among thieves?
        Whenever you talk about them you shake your heads in contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People of Moab, abandon your cities.
    Live among the cliffs.
        Be like doves that make their nests at the entrance of a cave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“We have heard about the arrogance of Moab’s people.
    They are very arrogant.
    They are very arrogant, conceited, and boastful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know how arrogant they are,” declares Yahweh,
    “but it isn’t right.
    They brag and don’t do what they say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I will weep for Moab and cry for all of Moab.
    I will moan for the people of Kir Hareseth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will cry for you as Jazer cries.
    I will cry for you, grapevines of Sibmah.
    Your branches once spread as far as the sea,
        and they reached as far as the sea of Jazer.
    The destroyer will destroy your ripened fruits and your grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joy and gladness have disappeared from the orchards and fields of Moab.
    I will stop the wine flowing from the winepresses.
        No one will stomp on grapes with shouts of joy.
            There will be shouts, but not shouts of joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The cry will be heard from Heshbon to Elealeh and Jahaz. It will be heard from Zoar to Horonaim and Eglath Shelishiyah. Even the streams of Nimrim will dry up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will stop those in Moab who come to worship sites, those who bring offerings to their gods,” declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “That is why I moan for Moab like a flute. I sound like a flute for the people of Kir Hareseth. The wealth they gained has disappeared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Every head is shaved, and every beard is cut off. There are gashes on every hand and sackcloth on every waist.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People in Moab will mourn on every rooftop and in every street. There will be mourning everywhere, because I will break Moab like a jar that no one wants,” declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “They will cry, ‘Look how Moab is defeated! Moab turns away in shame!’ Moab has become something ridiculed and something held in contempt by everyone around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“This is what Yahweh says:
The enemy will swoop down like eagles and spread their wings over Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The cities will be taken, and the fortified places will be captured.
    On that day Moab’s soldiers will be like women in childbirth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be destroyed as a nation,
    because it spoke against Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Disasters, pits, and traps are in store for those who live in Moab,”
    declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Whoever flees from a disaster will fall into a pit.
    Whoever climbs out of the pit will be caught in a trap.
    I will bring a year of punishment to Moab,” declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Those who flee will stand exhausted in the shadow of Heshbon.
    A fire will come out of Heshbon and a flame from Sihon.
        It will burn the foreheads of the people of Moab
            and the skulls of those noisy people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How horrible it will be for you, Moab.
    You people of Chemosh will die.
        Your sons will be taken away into exile,
            and your daughters will be taken away into captivity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I will restore Moab in the last days,” declares Yahweh.
The judgment against Moab ends here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh says about the people of Ammon:
Doesn’t Israel have any children? Doesn’t it have any heirs?
    Why, then, has the god Milcom taken over the inheritance
        of Gad’s descendants?
    Why do Milcom’s people live in Gad’s cities?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why the days are coming, declares Yahweh,
    when I will sound the battle cry against Rabbah,
        where the people of Ammon live.
            It will become a pile of rubble.
            Its villages will be burned down.
    Then Israel will take possession of its inheritance, says Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cry loudly, Heshbon, because Ai is destroyed.
    Cry, people of Rabbah, put on your sackcloth, and mourn.
    Run back and forth between the walls.
        Milcom will be taken away into captivity
            with its priests and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you brag about your valleys,
    your fertile valleys, you unfaithful people?
    You trust your treasures.
        You think, “Who would attack me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am going to bring terror on you from all around,
    declares Adonay Yahweh Tsebaoth.
        Everyone will be scattered.
        No one will gather the refugees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But afterward, I will return the captives of Ammon, declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth says about Edom:
Is there no longer any wisdom in Teman?
    Has wisdom disappeared from your people?
    Has their wisdom vanished?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn and run.
    Hide in deep caves, inhabitants of Dedan.
        When I punish them,
            I will bring disaster on the descendants of Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If people come to pick your grapes,
    won’t they leave a few grapes behind?
    If thieves come during the night,
    won’t they steal only until they’ve had enough?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet, I will strip the descendants of Esau.
    I will find their hiding places.
        They won’t be able to hide.
            Their children and relatives will be destroyed.
    None of their neighbors will say,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Abandon your orphans, and I will keep them alive.
    Your widows can trust me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Yahweh says: If those who don’t deserve to drink from the cup still drink from it, why should you go unpunished? You won’t go unpunished. You must drink from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I take an oath on myself, declares Yahweh, that Bozrah will become a pile of rubble. It will become something horrifying, ridiculed, ruined, and cursed. All its cities will lie in ruins permanently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I heard a message from Yahweh.
    A messenger was sent among the nations to say,
        “Assemble, and attack Edom.
            Get ready for battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Edom, I will make you the smallest of nations
    and despised among humanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have frightened other people.
    Your arrogance has deceived you.
        You live on rocky cliffs
            and occupy the highest places in the hills.
    Even though you build your nest as high as an eagle,
    I will bring you down from there,” declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Then Edom will become something horrible.
    Everyone who passes by it will be horrified
        and hiss at all its wounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Edom will be like Sodom, Gomorrah, and their neighboring cities
    when they were destroyed.
        No one will live there.
        No human will stay there,” says Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will suddenly chase them from their places
    like a lion coming out of the jungle
        along the Jordan River into pastureland.
            I will appoint over Edom whomever I choose.
                Who is like me? Who can challenge me?
                    Is there any leader who can stand up to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to the plans that Yahweh is making against Edom
    and the things he intends to do to those who live in Teman.
        He will surely drag away the little ones of the flock.
        He will surely destroy the pasture
            because of the people who live in Teman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth will quake at the sound of their downfall.
    The sound of their crying will be heard at the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The enemy will swoop down like eagles
    and spread their wings over Bozrah.
        On that day Edom’s soldiers will be like women in childbirth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is a message about Damascus.
“Hamath and Arpad are worried because they heard the bad news.
    They melt in fear.
    They are troubled like a sea that can’t be calmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people of Damascus are weak.
    They turn to flee, but panic grips them.
    Anguish and pain grip them like a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why isn’t that famous, happy city abandoned?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why its young men will die in the streets,
    and its soldiers will be silenced that day,”
        declares Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will set fire to the walls of Damascus
    and burn down Benhadad’s palaces.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is about the tribe of Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor that King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon defeated. This is what Yahweh says:
Get ready, attack Kedar,
    and loot the people from the east.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their tents and their flocks will be taken.
    Their tent curtains, utensils, and camels will be carried away.
    People will shout to them, “Terror is all around!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Run far away! Find a place to hide,
    inhabitants of Hazor, declares Yahweh.
    King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon has made plans against you
    and intends to attack you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Get ready! Attack the nation living peacefully and securely,
    declares Yahweh.
        It is a nation with no gates or bars.
        Its people live alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their camels will be taken as prizes.
    Their large herds will be taken as loot.
    I will scatter to the winds
        those who shave the hair on their foreheads.
    I will bring disaster on them from every side,
        declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hazor will be a place where only jackals live.
    It will become a permanent wasteland.
        No one will live there.
        No human will stay there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the rule of King Zedekiah of Judah, Yahweh spoke his word to the prophet Jeremiah about Elam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth says:
I’m going to break the bows of Elam’s archers,
    the most important weapon of their strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll bring the four winds
    from the four corners of heaven against Elam
        and scatter its people in every direction.
    There won’t be a nation
    where Elam’s refugees won’t go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll defeat the people of Elam in the presence of their enemies,
    in the presence of those who want to kill them.
    I’ll bring disaster with my burning anger, declares Yahweh.
    I’ll send armies after them until I put an end to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll set my throne in Elam and destroy its king and officials,
    declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But afterward, I’ll return the captives of Elam, declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that Yahweh spoke about Babylon and the land of the Babylonians through the prophet Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Announce this among the nations, and spread the news.
    Raise a flag, and announce it.
    Don’t hide anything.
